description: From Middle English aspien, espien (“to make covert observations of (a person or place) with hostile intent, to spy on; to seek to discover by spying; to act as a spy; to catch sight of, see; to look over, observe; to wait in ambush, to ambush; to plot against; to look for, seek to find; to inquire or look into, investigate; to discover, find”) [and other forms], from Old French espier (“to watch”) (modern French épier (“to keep an eye on, watch; to spy on; (dated) to watch for”)), from Vulgar Latin *spiāre, from Frankish *spehōn (“to look, peer; to spy”), from Proto-Germanic *spehōną (“to look, peer; to spy”), from Proto-Indo-European *speḱ- (“to look, observe, see”). Doublet of spy.

verbs.description: espy (third-person singular simple present espies, present participle espying, simple past and past participle espied)

entries.meaning: To find out or observe (someone or something, especially if not easy to see) by spying or looking; to catch sight of; to see; to spot.
examples: Synonyms: descry, discern, discover; see also Thesaurus:spot
to espy land    to espy a man in a crowd

entries.meaning: To see (someone or something) without foreplanning or unexpectedly.
To observe (someone or something) as a spy; also, to examine or observe (someone or something) carefully; or to look out or watch for.
To become aware of (a fact, information, etc.).
(intransitive, archaic) To observe as a spy, to spy; also, to examine or observe carefully; or to look out or watch.

description:
From Middle English aspie, espie (“covert investigation or observation, scouting, spying; information obtained through spying; secret and treacherous plan, plot; treachery; a scout or spy”) [and other forms],
from Anglo-Norman espie, Old French espie, from espier (verb): see further at etymology 1.

entries.meaning: An act of finding out or observing by spying or looking; an espial or espying.
(uncountable) The act or process of learning secret information through clandestine means; espionage.
